And the sons of Dan said to him, “Do not let your voice be heard among us, lest men bitter of soul fall upon you, and you lose your life and the life of your household.”
And the sons of Dan went on their way; and when Micah saw that they were stronger than he, he turned and returned to his house.

And they took that which Micah had made, and the priest who had been his, and came upon Laish, upon a people quiet and trusting, and struck them with the edge of the sword, and burned the city with fire.
And there was no one to deliver, for it was far from Sidon, and they had no dealings with any man, and it was in the valley that belongs to Beth-rehob; and they built the city and dwelt in it.
And they called the name of the city Dan, after the name of Dan their father, who was born to Israel; but Laish was the name of the city at the first.

And the sons of Dan set up for themselves the carved image; and Jonathan, the son of Gershom, the son of Manasseh, he and his sons were priests to the tribe of the Danites until the day of the captivity of the land.
And they set up for themselves the carved image of Micah which he had made, all the days that the house of God was in Shiloh.

And it came to pass in those days, when there was no king in Israel, that there was a certain Levite sojourning in the remote parts of the hill country of Ephraim, and he took for himself a concubine out of Bethlehem in Judah.
But his concubine played the harlot against him, and went away from him to her father’s house, to Bethlehem of Judah, and she was there for four months.

Then her husband arose and went after her, to speak to her heart and bring her back; and his young man was with him, and a pair of donkeys. And she brought him into her father’s house, and when the girl’s father saw him, he rejoiced to meet him.
And his father-in-law, the father of the young woman, pressed him to stay; and he remained with him three days, and they ate and drank and lodged there.

And it came to pass on the fourth day, that they rose early in the morning, and he arose to depart; and the father of the young woman said to his son-in-law, Strengthen your heart with a morsel of bread, and afterward you shall go.
So they sat and the two of them ate together and drank, and the father of the young woman said to the man, “Consent now and lodge, and let your heart be merry.”
Then the man rose up to go, but his father-in-law pressed him, and he turned back and lodged there.
And he rose early in the morning on the fifth day to depart, and the father of the young woman said, “Strengthen now your heart, and linger until the day declines.” So the two of them ate.

And the man rose up to depart, he and his concubine and his servant; but his father-in-law, the father of the young woman, said to him, Behold now, the day has grown weak toward evening; lodge, I pray you, here. Behold, the day is declining; stay here that your heart may be merry, and tomorrow you shall rise early on your way, and go to your tent.
But the man was not willing to lodge there; so he rose and went, and came to the place opposite Jebus, that is Jerusalem, and with him were a pair of saddled donkeys, and his concubine was with him.
When they were near Jebus, and the day was far spent, the servant said to his master, “Come now, let us turn aside to this city of the Jebusites and lodge in it.”
But his master said to him, We will not turn aside into a foreign city that is not of the children of Israel; but we will pass over to Gibeah.
And he said to his young man, Come and let us draw near to one of the places, and we will lodge in Gibeah or in Ramah.
So they passed on and went their way, and the sun went down upon them near Gibeah, which belongs to Benjamin.
And they turned aside there to go in to lodge in Gibeah; and he went in and sat down in the open square of the city, but no man took them into his house to lodge.
And behold, an old man came from his work out of the field at evening; and the man was from the hill country of Ephraim, and he sojourned in Gibeah, but the men of the place were Benjaminites.
And he lifted up his eyes and saw the man, the traveler, in the open square of the city; and the old man said, “Where are you going, and from where do you come?”

And he said to me, We are passing from Bethlehem of Judah to the remote parts of the hill country of Ephraim; from there am I, and I went to Bethlehem of Judah, and I am going to the house of the LORD, but there is no man who will take me into his house.
And there is both straw and fodder for our donkeys, and also bread and wine for me, and for your maidservant, and for the young man who is with your servants; there is no lack of anything.
And the old man said, Peace be to you; only let all your want be upon me; only in the street do not lodge.
So he brought him into his house, and he gave fodder to the donkeys; and they washed their feet, and ate and drank.

While they were making their hearts merry, behold, the men of the city, worthless men, surrounded the house, beating on the door. And they spoke to the man, the master of the house, the old man, saying, “Bring out the man who came into your house, that we may know him.”
And the man, the master of the house, went out to them and said to them, “No, my brothers, do not act wickedly, now that this man has come into my house; do not do this vile thing.”

Behold, here is my daughter, a virgin, and his concubine; let me, I pray you, bring them out, and you may humble them and do to them what seems good in your eyes; but to this man do not do this vile thing.

But the men would not listen to him, so the man seized his concubine and brought her out to them outside, and they knew her and abused her all the night until the morning, and they let her go at the dawning of the day.
And the woman came as morning drew near, and fell down at the doorway of the house of the man where her master was, until it was light.

And her master rose up in the morning and opened the doors of the house and went out to go on his way, and behold, the woman his concubine was fallen at the entrance of the house, and her hands were upon the threshold.
And he said to her, “Arise, and let us go,” but there was no answer. Then he took her upon the donkey, and the man rose up and went to his place.
When he came into his house, he took a knife, and laid hold on his concubine, and cut her, limb by limb, into twelve pieces, and sent her throughout all the territory of Israel.

And it shall be that everyone who sees it will say, “Such a thing has not been done nor seen from the day the children of Israel came up out of the land of Egypt until this day. Set your heart upon it, take counsel, and speak.”
Then all the children of Israel went out, and the congregation was assembled as one man, from Dan even to Beersheba, and the land of Gilead, to the LORD at Mizpah.
And the chiefs of all the people, all the tribes of Israel, took their stand in the assembly of the people of God, four hundred thousand men on foot, drawing the sword.
And the sons of Benjamin heard that the sons of Israel had gone up to Mizpah. And the sons of Israel said, “Speak now, how did this evil come to pass?”
And the Levite, the husband of the murdered woman, answered and said, I came to Gibeah that belongs to Benjamin, I and my concubine, to lodge.
And the lords of Gibeah rose up against me and surrounded the house against me by night; they thought to kill me, and my concubine they abused, and she died.
So I took hold of my concubine and cut her in pieces, and sent her throughout all the territory of the inheritance of Israel, for they have committed lewdness and outrage in Israel.
Behold, all you are sons of Israel; give here for yourselves word and counsel.
And all the people arose as one man, saying, We will not go, each man to his tent, neither will we turn aside, each man to his house.
And now this is the thing that we will do to Gibeah: we will go up against it by lot.

And we will take ten men of a hundred throughout all the tribes of Israel, and a hundred of a thousand, and a thousand of ten thousand, to fetch provision for the people, that they may do, when they come to Gibeah of Benjamin, according to all the vile folly that has been done in Israel.
So all the men of Israel were gathered against the city, knit together as one man.
And the tribes of Israel sent men through all the tribe of Benjamin, saying, What is this evil that has come to pass among you?

Now therefore, hand over the men, the sons of Belial, who are in Gibeah, that we may put them to death and purge the evil from Israel. But the children of Benjamin would not listen to the voice of their brothers, the children of Israel.
And the sons of Benjamin gathered themselves together out of the cities to Gibeah, to go out to battle against the sons of Israel.
And the sons of Benjamin were mustered on that day out of the cities, twenty and six thousand men drawing the sword, besides the inhabitants of Gibeah, who were mustered, seven hundred chosen men.
Out of all this people there were seven hundred chosen men, left-handed; every one of these could sling a stone at a hair and not miss.
And the men of Israel, apart from Benjamin, were mustered, four hundred thousand men drawing the sword; all these were men of war.

And they arose and went up to Bethel and inquired of God, and the children of Israel said, “Who shall go up for us first to the battle against the children of Benjamin?” And the LORD said, “Judah first.”
And the sons of Israel rose up in the morning and encamped against Gibeah.
And the men of Israel went out to battle against Benjamin, and the men of Israel set themselves in array for war against Gibeah.
And the sons of Benjamin came out of Gibeah, and on that day they struck down to the ground of Israel twenty and two thousand men.
And the men of Israel took courage and again set the battle in array in the place where they had set themselves in array on the first day.

And the sons of Israel went up and wept before the LORD until evening, and they inquired of the LORD, saying, “Shall I again draw near to battle against the sons of Benjamin my brother?” And the LORD said, “Go up against him.”
And the children of Israel drew near to the children of Benjamin on the second day.
And Benjamin went out against them from Gibeah on the second day, and they struck down among the sons of Israel again eighteen thousand men to the ground; all these were men who drew the sword.

Then all the children of Israel and all the people went up and came to Bethel and wept, and sat there before the LORD, and fasted that day until evening, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.
And the children of Israel inquired of the LORD, for the ark of the covenant of God was there in those days.

And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, stood before it in those days, saying, “Shall I yet again go out to battle against the children of Benjamin my brother, or shall I cease?” And the LORD said, “Go up, for tomorrow I will give him into your hand.”
And Israel set men in ambush against Gibeah round about.
And the children of Israel went up against the children of Benjamin on the third day, and set themselves in array against Gibeah, as at other times.

And the sons of Benjamin went out to meet the people; they were drawn away from the city, and they began to strike down of the people, slain as at other times, on the highways, of which one goes up to Bethel and one to Gibeah, in the field, about thirty men of Israel.
And the sons of Benjamin said, “They are struck down before us as at the first.” But the sons of Israel said, “Let us flee and draw them away from the city to the highways.”
And all the men of Israel rose up from their place and set themselves in array at Baal-tamar, and the ambush of Israel broke forth from its place, from the open field of Gibeah.
And there came against Gibeah ten thousand chosen men out of all Israel, and the battle was fierce; but they did not know that evil was touching them.
And the LORD struck Benjamin before Israel, and the children of Israel destroyed of Benjamin that day twenty and five thousand and one hundred men; all these were men who drew the sword.
And the sons of Benjamin saw that they were struck down. And the men of Israel gave place to Benjamin, because they trusted in the ambush that they had set against Gibeah.
And the ambush made haste and rushed upon Gibeah, and the ambush advanced and struck all the city with the edge of the sword.
Now the appointed sign between the men of Israel and the ambush was that they should make a great cloud of smoke rise up from the city.

And the men of Israel turned in the battle, and Benjamin began to strike down the slain among the men of Israel, about thirty men; for they said, Surely he is utterly smitten before us, as at the first battle.
And the signal began to rise from the city, a pillar of smoke, and Benjamin looked behind him, and behold, the whole city went up in smoke toward heaven.
And the men of Israel turned, and the men of Benjamin were dismayed, for they saw that evil had come upon them.
And they turned before the men of Israel to the way of the wilderness, but the battle clung close to them, and those who came out of the cities were destroying them in their midst.
They enclosed Benjamin, they pursued him, they overtook him at his resting place, as far as opposite Gibeah toward the sunrise.
And there fell of Benjamin eighteen thousand men; all these were men of valor.

And they turned and fled toward the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon, and they gleaned of them in the highways five thousand men, and they pursued hard after them to Gidom, and struck down of them two thousand men.
And all those who fell of Benjamin that day were twenty and five thousand men drawing the sword; all these were men of valor.
But six hundred men turned and fled to the wilderness, to the rock of Rimmon, and they dwelt in the rock of Rimmon four months.

And the men of Israel turned again upon the children of Benjamin, and struck them with the edge of the sword, from the city, men and beast, to all that was found; also all the cities that were found they sent up in flames.
Now the men of Israel had sworn in Mizpah, saying, “None of us shall give his daughter to Benjamin as a wife.”
And the people came to Bethel and sat there before God until evening, and they lifted up their voice and wept with great weeping.
And they said, Why, O LORD God of Israel, has this come to pass in Israel, that there should be missing today from Israel one tribe?
And it came to pass on the next day that the people rose early and built there an altar, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings.

And the sons of Israel said, “Who is there among all the tribes of Israel that did not come up in the assembly to the LORD?” For the great oath had been made concerning him who did not come up to the LORD to Mizpah, saying, “He shall surely be put to death.”
And the children of Israel were grieved for Benjamin their brother, and said, Today one tribe is cut off from Israel.
What shall we do for them that remain, for wives, seeing we have sworn by the LORD that we will not give them of our daughters for wives?
And they said, Who is there among the tribes of Israel that did not come up to the LORD at Mizpah? And behold, no man had come into the camp from Jabesh-gilead to the assembly.
And the people were mustered, and behold, there was not there a man from the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead.

And the congregation sent there twelve thousand men of the sons of valor, and commanded them, saying, Go and strike the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead with the edge of the sword, both the women and the little ones.
And this is the thing that you shall do: every male, and every woman who has known the lying with a male, you shall utterly destroy.

And they found among the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead four hundred young women, virgins, who had not known a man by lying with a male; and they brought them to the camp at Shiloh, which is in the land of Canaan.
And all the congregation sent and spoke to the sons of Benjamin who were in the rock of Rimmon, and they called to them for peace.
And Benjamin returned at that time, and they gave them the women whom they had kept alive from the women of Jabesh-gilead, but they did not find enough for them.
And the people repented for Benjamin, because the LORD had made a breach among the tribes of Israel.
And the elders of the congregation said, What shall we do for wives for those who remain, seeing a woman has been destroyed out of Benjamin?
And they said, There must be an inheritance for the survivors of Benjamin, that a tribe not be blotted out from Israel.
But we are not able to give them wives from our daughters, for the sons of Israel have sworn, saying, Cursed be he who gives a wife to Benjamin.

And they said, Behold, there is a feast of the LORD in Shiloh, from year to year, which is on the north of Bethel, on the east side of the highway that goes up from Bethel to Shechem, and on the south of Lebonah.
And they commanded the sons of Benjamin, saying, Go and lie in wait in the vineyards.

And you shall watch, and behold, if the daughters of Shiloh come out to dance in the dances, then you shall come out of the vineyards, and each man seize for himself a wife from the daughters of Shiloh, and go to the land of Benjamin.

And it shall be, when their fathers or their brothers come to contend with us, that we will say to them, Be gracious to us for their sakes, because we did not take for each man his wife in battle, for you did not give them to them at this time, that you should be guilty.

And the sons of Benjamin did so, and took wives, according to their number, from the dancers whom they had carried off; and they went and returned to their inheritance, and built the cities and dwelt in them.
And the children of Israel departed from there at that time, each man to his tribe and to his family, and they went out from there, each man to his inheritance.
In those days there was no king in Israel; each man did what was right in his own eyes.
